author: Robert Burns
poem_alt_title: DUAN FIRST . Duan , a term of Ossian's for the different divisions of a digressive Poem . See his Cath-Loda , Vol , 2. of M'Pherson's Translation .

lines.line_text: THE sun had clos'd the winter-day,
The Curlers quat their roaring play,
And hunger'd Maukin taen her way
While faithless snaws ilk step betray

stanzas.stanza_text:
THE sun had clos'd the winter-day,
The Curlers quat their roaring play,
And hunger'd Maukin taen her way
To kail-yards green,
While faithless snaws ilk step betray
Whare she has been.

lines.line_text: The lee-lang day had tir'd me;
And when the Day had clos'd his e'e,
Ben i' the Spence, right pensivelie,

stanzas.stanza_text:
The Thresher's weary flingin-tree,
The lee-lang day had tir'd me;
And when the Day had clos'd his e'e,
Far i' the West,
Ben i' the Spence, right pensivelie,
I gaed to rest.

lines.line_text: I sat and ey'd the spewing reek,
And heard the restless rattons squeak

stanzas.stanza_text:
There, lanely, by the ingle-cheek,
I sat and ey'd the spewing reek,
That fill'd, wi' hoast-provoking smeek,
The auld, clay biggin;
And heard the restless rattons squeak
About the riggin.

lines.line_text: All in this mottie, misty clime,
I backward mus'd on wasted time,
How I had spent my youthfu' prime,
But stringing blethers up in rhyme

stanzas.stanza_text:
All in this mottie, misty clime,
I backward mus'd on wasted time,
How I had spent my youthfu' prime,
An' done nae-thing,
But stringing blethers up in rhyme
For fools to sing.

lines.line_text: Had I to guid advice but harket,
I might, by this, hae led a market,
Or strutted in a Bank and clarket

stanzas.stanza_text:
Had I to guid advice but harket,
I might, by this, hae led a market,
Or strutted in a Bank and clarket
My Cash-Account;
While here, half-mad, half-fed, half-sarket,
Is a' th' amount.

lines.line_text: And heav'd on high my wauket loof,
To swear by a' yon starry roof,
That I, henceforth, would be rhyme-proof

stanzas.stanza_text:
I started, mutt'ring blockhead! coof!
And heav'd on high my wauket loof,
To swear by a' yon starry roof,
Or some rash aith,
That I, henceforth, would be rhyme-proof
Till my last breath —

lines.line_text: When click! the string the snick did draw;
And jee! the door gaed to the wa';
And by my ingle-lowe I saw,
Ye need na doubt, I held my whisht;
The infant aith, half-form'd, was crusht;
I glowr'd as eerie's I'd been dusht,
When sweet, like modest Worth, she blusht,
Were twisted, gracefu', round her brows,
I took her for some SCOTTISH MUSE,
And come to stop those reckless vows,

stanzas.stanza_text:
Green, slender, leaf-clad Holly-boughs
Were twisted, gracefu', round her brows,
I took her for some SCOTTISH MUSE,
By that same token;
And come to stop those reckless vows,
Would soon been broken.

lines.line_text: Was strongly marked in her face;
Her eye, ev'n turn'd on empty space,
Down flow'd her robe, a tartan sheen,
Till half a leg was scrimply seen;
And such a leg! my BESS, I ween,
Sae straught, sae taper, tight and clean,
Her Mantle large, of greenish hue,
Deep lights and shades, bold-mingling, threw
And seem'd, to my astonish'd view,
Here, rivers in the sea were lost;
There, mountains to the skies were tost:
Here, tumbling billows mark'd the coast,
There, distant shone, Art's lofty boast,
Here, DOON pour'd down his far-fetch'd floods;
Auld, hermit AIRE staw thro' his woods,
And many a lesser torrent scuds,
Low, in a sandy valley spread,
An ancient BOROUGH rear'd her head;
Still, as in Scottish Story read,

stanzas.stanza_text:
Low, in a sandy valley spread,
An ancient BOROUGH rear'd her head;
Still, as in Scottish Story read,
She boasts a Race,
To ev'ry nobler virtue bred,
And polish'd grace.

lines.line_text: A whisp'ring throb did witness bear
When with an elder Sister's air

stanzas.stanza_text:
With musing-deep, astonish'd stare,
I view'd the heavenly-seeming Fair;
A whisp'ring throb did witness bear
Of kindred sweet,
When with an elder Sister's air
She did me greet.

lines.line_text: ' In me thy native Muse regard!
'Nor longer mourn thy fate is hard,
'I come to give thee such reward,

stanzas.stanza_text:
'All hail! my own inspired Bard!
' In me thy native Muse regard!
'Nor longer mourn thy fate is hard,
' Thus poorly low!
'I come to give thee such reward,
' As we bestow.

lines.line_text: 'Know, the great Genius of this Land,
' Has many a light, aerial band,

stanzas.stanza_text:
'Know, the great Genius of this Land,
' Has many a light, aerial band,
'Who, all beneath his high command,
' Harmoniously,
'As Arts or Arms they understand,
' Their labors ply.

lines.line_text: ' Some fire the Sodger on to dare;
'Some rouse the Patriot up to bare
'Some teach the Bard, a darling care,

stanzas.stanza_text:
''Mong swelling floods of reeking gore,
' They ardent, kindling spirits pour;
'Or, mid the venal Senate's roar,
' They, sightless, stand,
'To mend the honest Patriot-lore,
'And grace the hand.

lines.line_text: ' The rustic Bard, the lab'ring Hind,
' All chuse, as, various they're inclin'd,

stanzas.stanza_text:
'To lower Orders are assign'd,
'The humbler ranks of Human-kind,
' The rustic Bard, the lab'ring Hind,
'The Artisan;
' All chuse, as, various they're inclin'd,
'The various man.

lines.line_text: ' The threat'ning Storm, some, strongly, rein;
' Some grace the Maiden's artless smile;
' Explore at large Man's infant race,
' And careful note each op'ning grace,

stanzas.stanza_text:
'Some, bounded to a district-space,
' Explore at large Man's infant race,
'To mark the embryotic trace,
'Of rustic Bard;
' And careful note each op'ning grace,
'A guide and guard.

lines.line_text: 'Of these am I — COILA my name;
' And this district as mine I claim,
'Where once the Campbell's, chiefs of fame,

stanzas.stanza_text:
'Of these am I — COILA my name;
' And this district as mine I claim,
'Where once the Campbell's, chiefs of fame,
' Held ruling pow'r:
'I mark'd thy embryo-tuneful flame,
' Thy natal hour.

lines.line_text: 'With future hope, I oft would gaze,
' Fond, on thy little, early ways,

stanzas.stanza_text:
'With future hope, I oft would gaze,
' Fond, on thy little, early ways,
'Thy rudely-caroll'd, chiming phrase,
' In uncouth rhymes,
'Fir'd at the simple, artless lays
' Of other times.

lines.line_text: 'I saw thee seek the sounding shore,
'Or when the North his fleecy store

stanzas.stanza_text:
'I saw thee seek the sounding shore,
' Delighted with the dashing roar;
'Or when the North his fleecy store
' Drove thro' the sky,
'I saw grim Nature's visage hoar,
' Struck thy young eye.

lines.line_text: 'I saw thee eye the gen'ral mirth

stanzas.stanza_text:
'Or when the deep-green-mantl'd Earth,
' Warm-cherish'd ev'ry floweret's birth,
'And joy and music pouring forth,
' In ev'ry grove,
'I saw thee eye the gen'ral mirth
' With boundless love.

lines.line_text: ' Call'd forth the Reaper's rustling noise,
'I saw thee leave their ev'ning joys,

stanzas.stanza_text:
'When ripen'd fields, and azure skies,
' Call'd forth the Reaper's rustling noise,
'I saw thee leave their ev'ning joys,
' And lonely stalk,
'To vent thy bosom's swelling rise,
'In pensive walk.

lines.line_text: 'I taught thee how to pour in song,

stanzas.stanza_text:
'When youthful Love, warm-blushing, strong,
' Keen-shivering shot thy nerves along,
'Those accents, grateful to thy tongue,
' Th' adored Name,
'I taught thee how to pour in song,
'To soothe thy flame.

lines.line_text: 'But yet the light that led astray,

stanzas.stanza_text:
'I saw thy pulse's maddening play,
' Wild-send thee Pleasure's devious way,
'Misled by Fancy's meteor-ray,
' By Passion driven;
'But yet the light that led astray,
' Was light from Heaven.

lines.line_text: ' The loves, the ways of simple swains,
'Till now, o'er all my wide domains,
' And some, the pride of Coila's plains,

stanzas.stanza_text:
'I taught thy manners-painting strains,
' The loves, the ways of simple swains,
'Till now, o'er all my wide domains,
'Thy fame extends;
' And some, the pride of Coila's plains,
'Become thy friends.

lines.line_text: 'Thou canst not learn, nor I can show,
' Or pour, with Gray, the moving flow,

stanzas.stanza_text:
'Yet all beneath th'unrivall'd Rose,
' The lowly Daisy sweetly blows;
'Tho' large the forest's Monarch throws
' His army shade,
'Yet green the juicy Hawthorn grows,
' Adown the glade.

lines.line_text: ' Strive in thy humble sphere to shine;

stanzas.stanza_text:
'Then never murmur nor repine
' Strive in thy humble sphere to shine;
'And trust me, not Potosi's mine,
' Nor Kings regard,
'Can give a bliss o'ermatching thine,
'A rustic Bard

lines.line_text: 'To give my counsels all in one,
'And wear thou this' — She solemn said,
And bound the Holly round my head:
The polish'd leaves, and berries red,
And, like a passing thought, she fled,

stanzas.stanza_text:
'And wear thou this' — She solemn said,
And bound the Holly round my head:
The polish'd leaves, and berries red,
Did rustling play;
And, like a passing thought, she fled,
In light away.
